displayed_text: Family Member: And we will have a number to call? Doctor: Oh yeah, yep. And I do want to mention as you’re talking about this, he’s also an Iron Man candidate. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: So in our quest to always get you the most number of trials Mr. W____ that you’re eligible for, (HCP laughs) Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - so that I know and everyone else knows how you’re doing, how you’re feeling – Patient: Um. Doctor: - so that your experience gets you know out there Family Member: Right now as I say… Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: He to me… Doctor: Um hmm.

Patient: None of that. Doctor: And how just overall energy level since we stopped the study have you had? Noticed worsening, better, same? Patient: Well, uh, I could say, I don’t have as much energy as I had when I was on testosterone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right? So that, that has diminished. Uh, uh, let’s see, I, I’m just trying to think through the process because I’m still- Doctor: I mean, you’re still up? You’re still kind of doing the things you want to do? You’re not like-? Patient: Right. Right. Right. Right. Right. Yeah. Because we was on vacation for twelve days. So that, that threw off everything with me. Doctor: Since I saw you last? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Where’d you guys go? Patient: South Africa. Doctor: Oh, that’s right. How was that? Patient: Oh, mind blowing.

Healthcare Professional: If they’re available. Patient: I don’t think there’s really any hard dates that we need to have or need to work around- Family Member: I can’t think of any. Patient: in the next month or two. Well, you’ll scheduled to be the driver. Family Member: No. Oh, no it won’t. I mean they told multiple times they’ll work with me and so that is not lip service. Patient: Larry said he’d be willing to, as long as, he’s thinking, two to three hours. Or if he can get me here, somebody will get me out. Healthcare Professional: Uh, yes. CALLER Good afternoon, Infusion, this is M_. Doctor: M_ in charge? CALLER Yes. Family Member: Umm, will the, will the chemo class help me understand what my, what I need to do to protect him from whatever I’m supposed to protect him from? Doctor: Uh, yes, I mean, they will allow you to ask questions about anything you should be worried about, things you’ve heard, and you can go from there as to sort of whether should you worry or not worry. Umm. And so these are people that have been through it with a lot of people, so they should be able to guide you about what, you know, what’s real worry and what’s not real worry. Family Member: So, we’re normally the household that people come to for Christmas, probably twenty five people. Depending on where we are in the scheme of things, do I want that many people around? Doctor: Uh, right. So, when you pick your date for chemo with T_,

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Particularly because you’re not really symptomatic right now, I don’t think, and, you know, the, the benefits of both, uh, are about the same. Uh, so, and the side effects of chemotherapy are just, you know-? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: More to deal with. So, so if we were going to choose, uh, I would probably choose one of the hormone pills as the next thing to do. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the clinical trials that we have, uh, at this point, uh, whether you’re ready to do another clinical trial after having just been on one. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, the one upside of clinical trials is, you might of noticed, is you get a research nurse who kind of is like your concierge who runs everything for you.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But sometimes it's vacation and special events and life. Patient: . Right now. Family Member: Okay, what if he goes on chemo- Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful.

Family Member: There you go S___. Doctor: Living is very important but we can't do it with you laid up in bed doing nothing and just say well it's good we got the prostate cancer all taken care of. Family Member: Right that’s not good. Doctor: I say that all the time too. Patient: The one on my ribs doesn't bother me. Doctor: It doesn’t bother you. Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine. Doctor: Yeah, they won't be subtle when they decide to act tough. You're gonna feel it. It's not the occasional, Oh, that kind of hurts. It's the oh man this day hurts every day. Family Member: He has body aches, constantly, his whole body aches and I'm trying to figure out what's causing these body aches. It's like he sat there the other day and was telling me how he was feeling and I know this is terrible, but I started laughing because and I know I was not laughing at you. Yeah, I feel overwhelmed. Like there's nothing I can do. Patient: I’ve been going to a chiropractor for 15 years. Almost on a weekly basis Doctor: Yeah. Patient: To get my back adjusted. They adjust my upper back and my lower back and they adjust my neck. Family Member: But this all over body aching is how long.

Patient: No, I’ve just seen my regular doctor. Family Member: He just told me. He was hiding it from me. Doctor: Ah. Well, you know, getting that sort of worked out because we could always do that in the between. Just because this is a six month go Patient: Right. Okay. Okay. Doctor: we can always pause because hernia surgery is outpatient nowadays too so you just need healing time. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this stuff only goes to bone and your hernia surgery is not bone so it’s all workable. Patient: Okay they may say it’s not necessary either. Doctor: Yeah, correct, correct, but go ahead and have your primary refer you to a hernia surgeon. Okay? Patient: Okay, yep. Doctor: Might as well get that all taken care of. Patient: Okay, alright. Well, this sounds good to me.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think we’re probably hitting the bottom. Uh, which is okay. I, I think we have to sort of see how long we live there. Um. The, uh, the other thing that came back was your DNA test. Patient: The genetics. Doctor: Yeah, did you see that or not? Patient: No! I didn’t get a copy that I’m aware of. Uh, did you get it? Doctor: Yeah. So, it actually looks like, uh, (coughs) Patient: Positive as in good news? Or – Doctor: No, that you’ve got a mutation. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, so, it’s kinda letting the genie out of the bottle a little bit once I tell you the results. Because, it has, you know, significance for your family. Family Member: And that’s what I was going to ask you. Patient: Hey! I want to know.

Patient: though too and this question that - Doctor: remember this is a marathon race. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can’t sprint from thing to thing you’ll be exhausted – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and we won’t go anywhere. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we’re pacing you. Mm,hmm. Family Member: So, we’ve got four or five more chemos… Doctor: Yeah I think… Family Member: And then we’ll do a scan? Patient: Did you count this as one? Doctor: That was one. So I think we just need to sort of…

Patient: And that’s what is kind of annoying you know that - Doctor: Yeah, that we could not have continued it. Patient: At least - Doctor: But you really had a off-the-chart benefit with that. Okay. Agreed. Patient: And if I had you know two more treatments, would it have been enough you know? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Patient: It didn’t affect me Doctor: Safety-wise, right now it’s only six months, you know. And there are some unexpected effects that are coming out for radium with um Zytiga because people have had, well there’s no problems with just adding the radium- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH!

Patient: Oh sure Doctor: But, if you don’t have any nausea, we have done everything that we needed to do and you feel great, you’ve got company to talk about – Hey, that wasn’t so bad. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: But, yeah, uh, you’ve gotta have a partner on those days. Patient: That’s fine. Just wanted to Doctor: There is no need to stay. She could leave for a couple of hours and come back. (chuckles) Family Member: Mmmmm. Doctor: Umm, but. Patient: How long then is, I know the infusion is like half an hour or something? Healthcare Professional: It’s an hour. Patient: It’s an hour. Okay. Then, how long before I get released? Doctor: Uh, the first time, they watch it for a half hour or so just to make sure you don’t have an allergic reaction.

Patient: Yeah, that's better. The pain-- Doctor: Okay. Patient: is, the drops help on that. There's no pain, the throb it’s not there. Doctor: Alright, then now let me see though (whispering) Patient: You were just covering it a little bit there. (pause) Doctor: This one is weeping? Patient: No, that's a, uh, a wart. I covered up. Doctor: Ok, alright. When did that thing--that wasn't there was it, last time? Patient: Well, it’s when cold weather hits it seems like to grow. Doctor: Oh you see, so you get these any way. Patient: Yeah, I go to the Dermanolog, Dermatologist for it. Doctor: Ok.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So here are the orders themselves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Again, this should have been submitted to LabCorp. But if you don’t have them, instead of calling over and having to get it faxed, you can hold onto that. Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you, sir. Doctor: I will see you both in January. Patient: In January and then Doctor: The date we picked, it was the seventeenth. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: The timing, the timing and the schedule . Okay, so have a nice holiday season. Patient: Okay, you, too. Have a safe trip. Thank you. Doctor: Nice to see both of you.

Family Member: So continue with the Lupron, and every four months is what she gets us. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So what’s, what’s the deal at the (coughs) Doctor: Well, the trial is done. They are still analyzing the results. So there’s no final results, yet. Patient: From what? Doctor: From the study you were on. Right? That’s what you’re asking? Patient: No. What I- you’re looking if I can get on it. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You’re looking at clinical trials, I guess. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I see. So, yeah, so that one is an option for you especially now that the PSA is going up slightly. If you want to do it, that is an option. Patient: What is it? Doctor: Okay. So what it is, is it’s a radiation, a type of radiation that you would get, but it’s tagged to something called PSMA.

Family Member: It’s still two years. So you don’t gain any time. Doctor: We don’t think so. Patient: What if we had castrate level Doctor: Quite frankly, we’re too nervous to you know; the first thing we’re trying to do is cure you. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And uh they were pretty; um, the lab studies were done in two years were sort of a minimum time in this setting. Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Doctor: Yeah and we give the chemo and the super hormones for three months. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then give you about time to recover about six to eight weeks later. Then we do the radiation, uh which puts you at about sort of eight months, you know out, so then you’d have another; it’s a total of two years of hormones. Patient: Okay and then how frequently will my PSA be tested while I’m doing the chemo? Doctor: Every month.
